STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 2, 2020
Donata Kidd
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
RE: License #: CP610201318
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
Dear Ms. Kidd:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on October 22,
2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, and ISEP requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the ISEP. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the previous corrective
action plan was unsuccessful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(616) 204-6992
enclosure
Kathy Miller, BSC Director
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
AMENDED
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP610201318
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Muskegon County DHHS
Facility Address: 2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
Facility Telephone #: (231) 733-3700
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1992
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): October 13, 2020 via TEAMS

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Three of eleven employee files reviewed requiring a written evaluation were not
completed as required.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Two of three foster home files reviewed requiring a renewal application submission
was not provided with the application at least 60 days in advance.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of three foster home files reviewed requiring a renewal inspection, the
reevaluation recommendation was not made to the department at least 15 calendar
days prior to expiration.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
4

(a) All non-compliances relating to the recommendation
are correctable.
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed.
The plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible,
the time frames for correction; methods for
ensuring the safety of any children placed in the
home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved;
consequences if the corrective action plan is not
completed; and what documentation will be
required to demonstrate compliance or
completion.
(ii) Require that the corrective action be completed
within six (6) months of being signed.
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the agency.
One of six foster home files reviewed documented the family was in non-compliance
as they could not verify the family’s water temperature however were found in full
compliance and no corrective action plan was developed as required.
One of six foster home files reviewed, lacked documentation of the foster parent
signature on the corrective action plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to
accept the foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
5

(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing
transaction record documents from the certifying agency.
(i) A copy of all special evaluations completed during the last 2
years.
Three of three borrowed bed files reviewed lacked documentation required in
subsection (a).
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed lacked documentation required in
subsection (c) and (d).
Two of three borrowed bed files reviewed lacked documentation required in
subsection (f) and (g).
R 400.12404 Placement.
(1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is
legally related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a licensed
foster home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
In one of eight foster care files reviewed, the agency recommended a child be
placed in a fictive kin placement. The agency placed the child with the fictive kin on
3/12/20; however, a signed court order was dated 4/22/20.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with
a relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of
the following information:
6

(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of
the change, except when prior notification would
jeopardize the child’s care or safety. If prior notice
is not provided, then the agency shall notify the
foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning
the change in placement.
Four of six foster home files reviewed where a change of placement occurred lacked
documentation of the required information in subsections (a) through (h) as required
that would be captured on an action summary. It was noted in some files an action
summary was located but completed months after the placement change occurred.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Two of six foster home files reviewed where a change of placement occurred lacked
documentation the foster parent was notified in writing of the placement change at
least 14 days in advance as required in subsection (i). This would have been
captured on a DHS-30.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care.
7

Six of eight foster care files reviewed lacked documentation the provider was
provided with the required information in subsections (a) through (i) which would
have been captured on the initial placement outline.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed lacked documentation the providers were
given authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care as captured by
the DHS-3762.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of eleven foster care files reviewed had updated service plans completed
greater than every 90 calendar days. One file had two service plans that were late
by 84, and 8 days. The second file had two service plans that were late by 84, and
21 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from
the child, the child’s parents or legal guardian, foster
parents, referring agency, and others, unless the agency
documents why any of these entities cannot be involved.
One of eleven foster care files reviewed lacked updated information in the updated
service plans. Of the four service plans reviewed, the information within the reports
remained the same.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
Two of three independent living youth files reviewed lacked documentation that
youth were provided with the program statement prior to placement.
8

R 400.12503 Policies and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
Two of three independent living youth files reviewed lacked documentation that
youth were provided with the agency’s policies and procedures as required.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for
the specific program the youth is being placed into.
(b) The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits self-
care potential.
(c) That the youth’s social service worker has personally
observed and determined that the living situation is safe
and that the youth has a bed and has access to cooking
and bathing facilities.
(d) The availability of specific and relevant resources that
may provide for suitable social, physical, educational,
vocational, and emotional needs of a youth.
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and a
plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
Two of three independent living youth files reviewed lacked documentation required
in subsections (a) through (f).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at
least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
9

updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three independent living youth files reviewed lacked a mutually agreed
upon contract covering subsections (a) through (d) and updated every 90 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
One of three independent living files reviewed lacked documentation of the worker
having monthly face to face visits with the youth in their residence each month as
required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. IF the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up action s to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Seven of eleven open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required signatures
on the parent agency agreement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED-Previously cited under 722-08c
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight
Supervisors shall meet a least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status of progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
10

has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
Two of eleven open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
supervision as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED- Previously cited under 6.30
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
ISEP 6.21 Visits, Worker-Child
(a)Each child in foster care shall be visited by a caseworker at
least two time per month during the child’s first two months of
placement in an initial or new placement, and at least one time
per month thereafter. At least one visit each month shall take
place at the child’s placement location and shall include a
private meeting between the child and the caseworker.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of at least
two face to face visits within the first two months of placement.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
visits between the worker and child in subsequent months as required.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(a) For each child in foster care with a permanency goal of
reunification, the child’s caseworker shall have face-to-face
contacts with the child’s parent(s) as follows:
(1) for the first month the child is in care, two face-to-face
contact with each parent, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s place of residence.
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face
contact with each parent and phone contact as needed, with
at least on contact in each three-month period occurring in
the parent’s place of residence.
One of six open foster care case files reviewed with a goal of reunification lacked
documentation of monthly contact with the parent as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note that there
are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements except for the
following:
11

SRM 200 Fingerprints
Personnel Training
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes SAT timely.
Based on review of the Learning Management System (LMS) employee transcripts,
five current employees and one former employee were found to be in non-
compliance to timely certification of Security Awareness Training (SAT).
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Four of seven open foster care youth files reviewed lacked the required caregiver
signatures timely, which would indicate their involvement in the plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
12

In six of eleven open foster care youth files reviewed, the Case Plan Development/
Reassessment Family Team Meeting was not completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
In three of eleven open foster care youth files reviewed, the activity report (DHS
1105) was not uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
In two of three files reviewed requiring a semi-annual transition plan be completed,
lacked documentation one was completed as required.
FOM 722-3 Placement Selection and Standards
Residential Placement Exception Request
13

Two of two open foster youth files reviewed requiring a residential placement
exception request was not completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
One of one open foster youth files reviewed where siblings were split lacked a sibling
split placement exception request.
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval - USP
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
One of nine open foster care youth files reviewed the supervisor did not approve a
case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements
Five of eleven open case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being completed
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
Interim Inspection 11/13/18, CAP approval dated 12/7/18
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Dental Examination Schedule
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every 6
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Three of eleven open foster care files reviewed requiring a dental examination within
6 months was not completed as required. (NOTE: Communication Issuance in
14

November 2019 requiring dentals for all youth ages one and older every 6 months.
Communication was provided to field if could not arrange due to COVID-19, a note
be placed in the upkept appointments in MiSACWIS).
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in a
case, including:
 Child fatality.
 Change in caseworker or organization.
 Change in parent contact information.
 Foster care transfer to adoption.
 Change in placement.
 Temporary break from placement.
Program or case closing.
One of six closed foster care youth files reviewed lacked the closing action summary.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection 8/28/19, CAP approval dated 9/19/19
FOM 722-3B Relative Engagement and Placement
Relative Placement Home Study
The DHS-3130A, Relative Placement Home Study, is a
comprehensive home assessment that considers multiple
domains in a prospective caregiver's life. The Relative Placement
Home Study allows caseworkers to identify strengths and barriers
that may impact a child's placement. The Relative Placement
Home Study must be completed within the timeframes described
below:
 For emergency placements, within 30 calendar
days of the child’s placement in the relative home.
Out of State Child Abuse and Neglect Registry and Criminal
History Checks.
A caregiver or adult household member who has resided outside
of the State of Michigan's jurisdiction, for example, another state,
country, territory, or tribal jurisdiction, within the last five years
must have a child abuse/neglect registry check and a criminal
15

history background check from all previous places of residence
during those five years.
Out-of-state clearances must be requested no later than 72-hours
after an emergency placement and prior to a planned placement.
The out-of-state requests and responses must be documented on
the Relative Placement Safety Screen and Relative Placement
Home Study and any correspondence received pertaining to the
request must be uploaded in MiSACWIS.
Director Approval
Approval from the county director, designated child welfare
director, or private child placing agency director is required prior
to an emergency placement with:
 A caregiver who was confirmed as a perpetrator on
a prior CPS investigation.
 A caregiver or adult household member who has a
conviction of a good moral character offense.
One of four relative home study’s reviewed was completed over 30 days after
placement.
One of four relative home studies reviewed documented out of state clearances were
requested but no results were obtained prior to the study being completed.
One of four relative initial safety screenings where a member of the household had
criminal history requiring the director approve the placement, the director did not
approve in MiSACWIS as required.
SRM 103 Staff Qualifications and Training
MDHHS and private caseload-carrying staff and specialized
support staff must complete 32 hours of in-service training each
calendar year.
One of four employee files of employees who have been employed for over one year,
lacked documentation of 32 hours of in-service training each calendar year as
required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Special Evaluations were hard to follow and understand how the agency
reached their conclusion. There was information in the analysis section that
was not specifically provided in the investigation section to know how the
information was gathered and confirmed. The agency was informed all
16

information must be included in the methodology section of the report, so the
reader has a full understanding of the facts.
 A discussion occurred regarding consistency in licensing action
recommendations based on the citation. It was recommended previous
investigations be reviewed as the licensing workers change as well secondary
review of licensing action investigations.
 Clarification of independent living rule requirement was provided when a
youth has a legal status of Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care. For any youth
placed in an independent living placement, regardless of their legal status, the
Independent Living Section of the Child Placing Agency rules apply.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The licensing supervisor was provided with consultation regarding opening up a
special investigation if the agency receives information of alleged rule non-
compliance regardless of the complainant and information the foster care worker
could provide.
VI. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts found during the Field Analyst visits to licensed foster
homes and unlicensed caregiver homes.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
The agency initiated a special investigation, collaborated with other parties and
made an appropriate recommendation to revoke the foster home license.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency initiated special investigation to address each situation. The agency
completed investigations, interviewed appropriate parties, and made findings based
on the information gathered. One concern is consistency of agency
recommendations based on the findings throughout each case. Case A the foster
parent admitted to slapping a child in the face and the agency found the home in
non-compliance and recommended no change to the license. Case B the foster
parents, and three youth deny the foster parent swatted a child on the hand. One
youth stated the foster parent swatted on the hand. The agency found the home in
non-compliance and recommended a provisional license. The agency referenced
the Case B history of alleged corporal punishment. In two years, the home had five
investigations, where they were found in non-compliance in 2018 for corporal
punishment. The other three investigations had no findings. Case C the foster
17

parent admitted to grabbing a youth’s face and having youth perform physical
exercise as forms of punishment. The home was found in non-compliance and
recommended no change to the license.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2019 Renewal
Inspection Report.
The agency had 16 repeat violations during this period under review. Nine of the
sixteen repeat violations impacted over 50% of the case files reviewed. During this
period under review the agency’s administration changed significantly, having a new
DHHS Director and new Program Managers in both Foster Care and Child
Protective Services. The COVID-19 pandemic occurred, requiring staff to work from
home. The agency experienced typical levels of staff turnover. During staff
interviews, they reported an overall satisfaction with supervision and support
provided by direct supervisors and upper management. Staff felt impacted by the
COVID-19 pandemic but reported Muskegon DHHS did well making necessary
changes to meet the employees’ needs. Staff were in compliance with and happy
with their caseload sizes.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
November 2, 2020
